text: CHAPTER I
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Here is a story that has lain dormant for seven hundred years. At first
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: it was suppressed by one of the Plantagenet kings of England. Later it
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: was forgotten. I happened to dig it up by accident. The accident being
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the relationship of my wife's cousin to a certain Father Superior in a
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: very ancient monastery in Europe.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: He let me pry about among a quantity of mildewed and musty manuscripts
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and I came across this. It is very interesting--partially since it is a
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: bit of hitherto unrecorded history, but principally from the fact that
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: it records the story of a most remarkable revenge and the adventurous
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: life of its innocent victim--Richard, the lost prince of England.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: In the retelling of it, I have left out most of the history. What
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: interested me was the unique character about whom the tale revolves--the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: visored horseman who--but let us wait until we get to him.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: It all happened in the thirteenth century, and while it was happening,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: it shook England from north to south and from east to west; and reached
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: across the channel and shook France. It started, directly, in the London
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: palace of Henry III, and was the result of a quarrel between the King
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and his powerful brother-in-law, Simon de Montfort, Earl of Leicester.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Never mind the quarrel, that's history, and you can read all about it at
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: your leisure. But on this June day in the year of our Lord 1243, Henry
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: so forgot himself as to very unjustly accuse De Montfort of treason in
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the presence of a number of the King's gentlemen.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: De Montfort paled. He was a tall, handsome man, and when he drew himself
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: to his full height and turned those gray eyes on the victim of his
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: wrath, as he did that day, he was very imposing. A power in England,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: second only to the King himself, and with the heart of a lion in him, he
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: answered the King as no other man in all England would have dared answer
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: him.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "My Lord King," he cried, "that you be my Lord King alone prevents Simon
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: de Montfort from demanding satisfaction for such a gross insult. That
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: you take advantage of your kingship to say what you would never dare say
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: were you not king, brands me not a traitor, though it does brand you a
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: coward."
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Tense silence fell upon the little company of lords and courtiers as
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: these awful words fell from the lips of a subject, addressed to his
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: king. They were horrified, for De Montfort's bold challenge was to them
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: but little short of sacrilege.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Henry, flushing in mortification and anger, rose to advance upon De
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Montfort, but suddenly recollecting the power which he represented, he
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: thought better of whatever action he contemplated and, with a haughty
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: sneer, turned to his courtiers.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Come, my gentlemen," he said, "methought that we were to have a turn
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: with the foils this morning. Already it waxeth late. Come, De Fulm! Come,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Leybourn!" and the King left the apartment followed by his gentlemen,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: all of whom had drawn away from the Earl of Leicester when it became
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: apparent that the royal displeasure was strong against him. As the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: arras fell behind the departing King, De Montfort shrugged his broad
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: shoulders, and turning, left the apartment by another door.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: When the King, with his gentlemen, entered the armory he was still
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: smarting from the humiliation of De Montfort's reproaches, and as he
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: laid aside his surcoat and plumed hat to take the foils with De Fulm,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: his eyes alighted on the master of fence, Sir Jules de Vac, who was
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: advancing with the King's foil and helmet. Henry felt in no mood for
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: fencing with De Fulm, who, like the other sycophants that surrounded
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: him, always allowed the King easily to best him in every encounter.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: De Vac he knew to be too jealous of his fame as a swordsman to permit
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: himself to be overcome by aught but superior skill, and this day Henry
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: felt that he could best the devil himself.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The armory was a great room on the main floor of the palace, off the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: guard room. It was built in a small wing of the building so that it
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: had light from three sides. In charge of it was the lean, grizzled,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: leather-skinned Sir Jules de Vac, and it was he whom Henry commanded to
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: face him in mimic combat with the foils, for the King wished to go with
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: hammer and tongs at someone to vent his suppressed rage.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: So he let De Vac assume to his mind's eye the person of the hated De
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Montfort, and it followed that De Vac was nearly surprised into an early
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and mortifying defeat by the King's sudden and clever attack.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Henry III had always been accounted a good swordsman, but that day
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: he quite outdid himself and, in his imagination, was about to run
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the pseudo De Montfort through the heart, to the wild acclaim of his
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: audience. For this fell purpose he had backed the astounded De Vac twice
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: around the hall when, with a clever feint, and backward step, the master
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: of fence drew the King into the position he wanted him, and with the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: suddenness of lightning, a little twist of his foil sent Henry's weapon
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: clanging across the floor of the armory.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: For an instant, the King stood as tense and white as though the hand of
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: death had reached out and touched his heart with its icy fingers.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The episode meant more to him than being bested in play by the best
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: swordsman in England--for that surely was no disgrace--to Henry it
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: seemed prophetic of the outcome of a future struggle when he should
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: stand face to face with the real De Montfort; and then, seeing in De
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Vac only the creature of his imagination with which he had vested the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: likeness of his powerful brother-in-law, Henry did what he should like
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: to have done to the real Leicester. Drawing off his gauntlet he advanced
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: close to De Vac.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Dog!" he hissed, and struck the master of fence a stinging blow across
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the face, and spat upon him. Then he turned on his heel and strode from
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the armory.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: De Vac had grown old in the service of the kings of England, but he
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: hated all things English and all Englishmen. The dead King John, though
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: hated by all others, he had loved, but with the dead King's bones De
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Vac's loyalty to the house he served had been buried in the Cathedral of
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Worcester.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: During the years he had served as master of fence at the English Court,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the sons of royalty had learned to thrust and parry and cut as only
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: De Vac could teach the art, and he had been as conscientious in the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: discharge of his duties as he had been in his unswerving hatred and
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: contempt for his pupils.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: And now the English King had put upon him such an insult as might only
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: be wiped out by blood.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: As the blow fell, the wiry Frenchman clicked his heels together, and
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: throwing down his foil, he stood erect and rigid as a marble statue
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: before his master. White and livid was his tense drawn face, but he
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: spoke no word.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: He might have struck the King, but then there would have been left to
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: him no alternative save death by his own hand; for a king may not fight
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: with a lesser mortal, and he who strikes a king may not live--the king's
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: honor must be satisfied.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Had a French king struck him, De Vac would have struck back, and gloried
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: in the fate which permitted him to die for the honor of France; but an
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: English King--pooh! a dog; and who would die for a dog? No, De Vac would
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: find other means of satisfying his wounded pride. He would revel in
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: revenge against this man for whom he felt no loyalty. If possible, he
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: would harm the whole of England if he could, but he would bide his time.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: He could afford to wait for his opportunity if, by waiting, he could
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: encompass a more terrible revenge.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: De Vac had been born in Paris, the son of a French officer reputed the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: best swordsman in France. The son had followed closely in the footsteps
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: of his father until, on the latter's death, he could easily claim the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: title of his sire. How he had left France and entered the service of
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: John of England is not of this story. All the bearing that the life of
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Jules de Vac has upon the history of England hinges upon but two of his
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: many attributes--his wonderful swordsmanship and his fearful hatred for
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: his adopted country.

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: companion, in gay colors. His tiny surcoat of scarlet velvet was rich
title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: silk. His doublet was of scarlet, while his long hose of white were
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: cross-gartered with scarlet from his tiny sandals to his knees. On the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn

text: little head.

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: young woman beneath him, but with eyes which did not see, for De Vac was
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: working out a great problem, the greatest of all his life.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: some means to be revenged upon the King for the insult which Henry had
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: put upon him. Many schemes had presented themselves to his shrewd
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and cunning mind, but so far all had been rejected as unworthy of the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: terrible satisfaction which his wounded pride demanded.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: His fancies had, for the most part, revolved about the unsettled
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: political conditions of Henry's reign, for from these he felt he might
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: wrest that opportunity which could be turned to his own personal uses
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and to the harm, and possibly the undoing, of the King.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: For years an inmate of the palace, and often a listener in the armory
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: when the King played at sword with his friends and favorites, De Vac had
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: heard much which passed between Henry III and his intimates that could
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: well be turned to the King's harm by a shrewd and resourceful enemy.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: With all England, he knew the utter contempt in which Henry held the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: terms of the Magna Charta which he so often violated along with his
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: kingly oath to maintain it. But what all England did not know, De Vac
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: had gleaned from scraps of conversation dropped in the armory: that
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and with Louis IX of France, for a sufficient force of knights and
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: men-at-arms to wage a relentless war upon his own barons that he might
title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: prerogative of the Plantagenets to misrule England.

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: point of landing of the foreign troops; their numbers; the first point
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: of attack. Ah, would it not be sweet revenge indeed to balk the King in
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: this venture so dear to his heart!

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the Thames, where a dull splash marked the end of the last hope that
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Prince Richard might be rescued from the clutches of his Nemesis.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: CHAPTER V
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: For three years following the disappearance of Prince Richard, a bent
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: old woman lived in the heart of London within a stone's throw of the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: King's palace. In a small back room she lived, high up in the attic of
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: an old building, and with her was a little boy who never went abroad
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: alone, nor by day. And upon his left breast was a strange mark which
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: resembled a lily. When the bent old woman was safely in her attic room,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: with bolted door behind her, she was wont to straighten up, and discard
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: her dingy mantle for more comfortable and becoming doublet and hose.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: For years, she worked assiduously with the little boy's education. There
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: were three subjects in her curriculum; French, swordsmanship and hatred
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: of all things English, especially the reigning house of England.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The old woman had had made a tiny foil and had commenced teaching the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: little boy the art of fence when he was but three years old.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "You will be the greatest swordsman in the world when you are twenty,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: my son," she was wont to say, "and then you shall go out and kill many
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Englishmen. Your name shall be hated and cursed the length and breadth
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: of England, and when you finally stand with the halter about your neck,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: aha, then will I speak. Then shall they know."
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The little boy did not understand it all, he only knew that he was
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: comfortable, and had warm clothing, and all he required to eat, and that
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: he would be a great man when he learned to fight with a real sword,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and had grown large enough to wield one. He also knew that he hated
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Englishmen, but why, he did not know.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Way back in the uttermost recesses of his little, childish head, he
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: seemed to remember a time when his life and surroundings had been very
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: different; when, instead of this old woman, there had been many people
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: around him, and a sweet faced woman had held him in her arms and kissed
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: him, before he was taken off to bed at night; but he could not be sure,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: maybe it was only a dream he remembered, for he dreamed many strange and
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: wonderful dreams.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: When the little boy was about six years of age, a strange man came to
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: their attic home to visit the little old woman. It was in the dusk of
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the evening but the old woman did not light the cresset, and further,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: she whispered to the little boy to remain in the shadows of a far corner
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: of the bare chamber.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The stranger was old and bent and had a great beard which hid almost
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: his entire face except for two piercing eyes, a great nose and a bit
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: of wrinkled forehead. When he spoke, he accompanied his words with many
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: shrugs of his narrow shoulders and with waving of his arms and other
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: strange and amusing gesticulations. The child was fascinated. Here was
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the first amusement of his little starved life. He listened intently to
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the conversation, which was in French.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "I have just the thing for madame," the stranger was saying. "It be a
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: noble and stately hall far from the beaten way. It was built in the old
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: days by Harold the Saxon, but in later times, death and poverty and the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: disfavor of the King have wrested it from his descendants. A few years
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: since, Henry granted it to that spend-thrift favorite of his, Henri de
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Macy, who pledged it to me for a sum he hath been unable to repay. Today
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: it be my property, and as it be far from Paris, you may have it for the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: mere song I have named. It be a wondrous bargain, madame."
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "And when I come upon it, I shall find that I have bought a crumbling
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: pile of ruined masonry, unfit to house a family of foxes," replied the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: old woman peevishly.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "One tower hath fallen, and the roof for half the length of one wing
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: hath sagged and tumbled in," explained the old Frenchman. "But the three
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: lower stories be intact and quite habitable. It be much grander even
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: now than the castles of many of England's noble barons, and the price,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: madame--ah, the price be so ridiculously low."
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Still the old woman hesitated.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Come," said the Frenchman, "I have it. Deposit the money with Isaac the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Jew--thou knowest him?--and he shall hold it together with the deed
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: for forty days, which will give thee ample time to travel to Derby and
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: inspect thy purchase. If thou be not entirely satisfied, Isaac the Jew
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: shall return thy money to thee and the deed to me, but if at the end
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: of forty days thou hast not made demand for thy money, then shall Isaac
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: send the deed to thee and the money to me. Be not this an easy and fair
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: way out of the difficulty?"
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The little old woman thought for a moment and at last conceded that
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: it seemed quite a fair way to arrange the matter. And thus it was
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: accomplished.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Several days later, the little old woman called the child to her.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "We start tonight upon a long journey to our new home. Thy face shall
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: be wrapped in many rags, for thou hast a most grievous toothache. Dost
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: understand?"
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "But I have no toothache. My teeth do not pain me at all. I--"
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: expostulated the child.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Tut, tut," interrupted the little old woman. "Thou hast a toothache,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and so thy face must be wrapped in many rags. And listen, should any ask
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: thee upon the way why thy face be so wrapped, thou art to say that thou
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: hast a toothache. And thou do not do as I say, the King's men will take
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: us and we shall be hanged, for the King hateth us. If thou hatest the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: English King and lovest thy life do as I command."
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "I hate the King," replied the little boy. "For this reason I shall do
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: as thou sayest."
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: So it was that they set out that night upon their long journey north
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: toward the hills of Derby. For many days they travelled, riding upon
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: two small donkeys. Strange sights filled the days for the little boy
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: who remembered nothing outside the bare attic of his London home and the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: dirty London alleys that he had traversed only by night.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: They wound across beautiful parklike meadows and through dark,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: forbidding forests, and now and again they passed tiny hamlets of
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: thatched huts. Occasionally they saw armored knights upon the highway,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: alone or in small parties, but the child's companion always managed to
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: hasten into cover at the road side until the grim riders had passed.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Once, as they lay in hiding in a dense wood beside a little open glade
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: across which the road wound, the boy saw two knights enter the glade
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: from either side. For a moment, they drew rein and eyed each other in
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: silence, and then one, a great black mailed knight upon a black charger,
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: cried out something to the other which the boy could not catch. The
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: other knight made no response other than to rest his lance upon his
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: thigh and with lowered point, ride toward his ebon adversary. For a
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: dozen paces their great steeds trotted slowly toward one another, but
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: men on their iron trapped chargers came together in the center of the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: glade, it was with all the terrific impact of full charge.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The lance of the black knight smote full upon the linden shield of his
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: foeman, the staggering weight of the mighty black charger hurtled upon
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the gray, who went down with his rider into the dust of the highway. The
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: momentum of the black carried him fifty paces beyond the fallen horseman
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: before his rider could rein him in, then the black knight turned to view
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the havoc he had wrought. The gray horse was just staggering dizzily to
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: his feet, but his mailed rider lay quiet and still where he had fallen.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: With raised visor, the black knight rode back to the side of his
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: vanquished foe. There was a cruel smile upon his lips as he leaned
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: toward the prostrate form. He spoke tauntingly, but there was no
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the black knight wheeled and rode on down the road until he had
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: disappeared from sight within the gloomy shadows of the encircling
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: forest.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The little boy was spell-bound. Naught like this had he ever seen or
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: dreamed.
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: woman.

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Shall I be clothed in armor and ride upon a great black steed?" he
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: asked.

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn

text: way."

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn

text: kill one another for little provocation or for no provocation at all.

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Several days after Norman of Torn's visit to the castle of Leicester,
title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: have speech with Simon de Montfort. The Earl received him, and as the
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: young man entered his presence, Simon de Montfort, sprang to his feet in
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: astonishment.

title: The Outlaw of Torn

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Montfort."

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: you be that Roger de Conde who rescued my daughter from the fellows of
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Peter of Colfax, the arms of the De Montforts are open to you.

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Bertrade has had your name upon her tongue many times since her return.

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: us of your valiant espousal of her cause, and the thanks of her brothers
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and mother await you, Roger de Conde.

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: saw you, I could not believe two men could be born of different mothers
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: mother."

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: by Princess Eleanor, his wife, and by Bertrade de Montfort. The girl was
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: frankly glad to see him once more and laughingly chide him because he

text: of Colfax.

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: my friend; that is still at large to be brought to me upon a golden

text: dish."

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Colfax will return."
title: The Outlaw of Torn

text: "The very words of the Outlaw of Torn," she said. "How many men be ye,

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: for the King's son; and in manner, and form, and swordsmanship, and your

title: The Outlaw of Torn

text: Conde."

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: say. It may not be a courtly speech or it may. I know nothing of courts

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn

text: face.

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Norman of Torn, in his ignorance of the ways of women, saw only
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: friendship in the little acts of Joan de Tany. His life had been a hard
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and lonely one. The only ray of brilliant and warming sunshine that had
title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: The Outlaw of Torn
